articles.headline: The Limbo of Asian Markets
articles.snippet: The global currency crisis has forced markets to confront weak commodity exports before strong domestic demand can help them recover their balance.
articles.abstract: The global currency crisis has forced markets to confront weak commodity exports before strong domestic demand can help them recover their balance.
articles.lead_paragraph: SURABAYA, Indonesia — The docks at big Indonesian ports like this one are quieter these days, as China’s demand for raw materials has begun to cool.

articles.headline: G.O.P. Senate Leaders Avert Debt Ceiling Crisis
articles.snippet: Senate Republican leaders rescued a measure to raise the nation’s borrowing limit, overcoming a threatened filibuster to clear the way for final approval.
articles.abstract: Senate Republican leaders rescued a measure to raise the nation’s borrowing limit, overcoming a threatened filibuster to clear the way for final approval.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — It was a moment of real drama in a chamber known for its somnambulism. Senator Mitch McConnell of Kentucky, the Republican leader, counted votes on his hand, at one point holding up three fingers as he searched for the remaining votes. Senator John Cornyn of Texas, his No. 2, paced the Senate floor.
articles.byline: By Ashley Parker and Jonathan Weisman

articles.headline: How to Survive the Next Wave of Technology Extinction
articles.snippet: So you bought a Betamax VCR? And also a Nook? Here’s a strategy to avoid betting on the wrong horse again.
articles.abstract: So you bought a Betamax VCR? And also a Nook? Here’s a strategy to avoid betting on the wrong horse again.
articles.lead_paragraph: Don’t mock the beleaguered Nook owner. That could have been you.

articles.headline: Conflict in Oil Industry, Awash in Crude
articles.snippet: The debate between oil producers and refiners over exports is a rare clash in a deeply guarded industry that involves arguments over national security, pricing at the pump and earnings.
articles.abstract: The debate between oil producers and refiners over exports is a rare clash in a deeply guarded industry that involves arguments over national security, pricing at the pump and earnings.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — T. Boone Pickens has personified the nation’s oil industry for more than a generation. So when he made an offhand comment at a conference here a few weeks ago expressing reservations about lifting the nation’s ban on exports of crude oil, he startled some of his old allies in the business.

articles.headline: Escaped Inmates From Iraq Fuel Syrian Insurgency
articles.snippet: Prison breakouts in Iraq have freed hundreds of militants who have joined radical Sunni groups operating in neighboring Syria and in Iraq itself.
articles.abstract: Prison breakouts in Iraq have freed hundreds of militants who have joined radical Sunni groups operating in neighboring Syria and in Iraq itself.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — A series of daring but little noticed breakouts from Iraqi prisons has freed hundreds of hardened militants who are now among the leaders and foot soldiers of the radical Sunni groups operating in neighboring Syria and, increasingly, in Iraq itself.
articles.byline: By Tim Arango and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: Over 1 Million Added to Rolls of Health Plan
articles.snippet: More than 1.1 million people signed up for health insurance through federal and state marketplaces in January, according to the government.
articles.abstract: More than 1.1 million people signed up for health insurance through federal and state marketplaces in January, according to the government.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — More than 1.1 million people signed up for health insurance through federal and state marketplaces in January, according to the government, and the number of young people enrolling increased faster than that of any other group.
articles.byline: By Michael D. Shear and Reed Abelson

articles.headline: Comcast Deal Seeks to Unite 2 Cable Giants
articles.snippet: Comcast has announced an agreement to acquire Time Warner Cable for more than $45 billion in stock, a deal that would combine the biggest and second-biggest cable television operators in the country.
articles.abstract: Comcast has announced an agreement to acquire Time Warner Cable for more than $45 billion in stock, a deal that would combine the biggest and second-biggest cable television operators in the country.
articles.lead_paragraph: Comcast announced on Thursday an agreement to acquire Time Warner Cable for more than $45 billion in stock, a deal that would combine the biggest and second-biggest cable television operators in the country.

articles.headline: Facebook Deal on Privacy Is Under Attack
articles.snippet: A class-action settlement intended to ensure that Facebook obtained consent before using people’s images or other data in ads is about to receive another legal challenge.
articles.abstract: A class-action settlement intended to ensure that Facebook obtained consent before using people’s images or other data in ads is about to receive another legal challenge.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Despite a class-action settlement in August that was supposed to ensure that Facebook users clearly consent to their comments, images and “likes” being used in ads, it has been business as usual on the service.

articles.headline: In Prison Release, Signs of Karzai’s Rift With U.S.
articles.snippet: American military officials have been publicly scathing in their criticism of the releases, which have brought relations between the two allies to a low point.
articles.abstract: American military officials have been publicly scathing in their criticism of the releases, which have brought relations between the two allies to a low point.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGRAM, Afghanistan — On Thursday at 9:10 a.m., the gates of the Bagram Prison swung open, and 65 men with long beards and new clothes walked out to freedom. The moment showed clearly just how thoroughly President Hamid Karzai had broken with the American military, here now 12 years.
articles.byline: By Jawad Sukhanyar and Rod Nordland

articles.headline: French Bank Is Suspected of Violating Blacklistings
articles.snippet: BNP Paribas is suspected of violating U.S. rules against doing business with countries like Iran and Cuba.
articles.abstract: BNP Paribas is suspected of violating U.S. rules against doing business with countries like Iran and Cuba.
articles.lead_paragraph: Updated, 8:42 p.m. | Consider it the Wall Street equivalent of a no-fly list. Banks are barred from doing business with countries that the United States government has blacklisted, like Cuba and Iran.
articles.byline: By Ben Protess and David Jolly

articles.headline: In Matter of Weeks, Meeting of Minds on Cable Giants’ Deal
articles.snippet: How Comcast’s $45 billion deal for Time Warner Cable came to be.
articles.abstract: How Comcast’s $45 billion deal for Time Warner Cable came to be.
articles.lead_paragraph: Updated, 9:14 p.m. | For months, a scrappy cable upstart thought it had Time Warner Cable on the run.
